title: Graph
definition: A graph $G$ consists of $V(G)$, a set of vertices (often also called nodes) and $E(G)$, a set of edges.

title: Simple graph
definition: Has no loops or double edges. Can be connected or disconnected.

title: Complete graph
definition: $K_n:=G$ on $n$ vertices is defnines by joining all pairs of vertices with an edge of $G$.

title: Empty graph
definition: Is the one in which no two vertices are adjacent.

title: Connected graph
definition: A graph is connected if, for every partition of its vertex set into two nonempty sets $X$ and $Y$, there is an edge with one end in $X$ and one end in $Y$.

title: The degree of a vertex
definition: Is the number of edges that are incident of $v$ vertex.

title: Neighborhood
definition: Set of all vertices sharing an edge with $v$.

title: k-regular
definition: Is one that has $deg(v)=k$ for all $v \in V$. A regular graph is one that is $k-regular$ for some $k$.

title: $K_n$
definition: Is a complete graph on $n$ vertices.

title: Bipartite graph
definition: Has two sets of vertices, where in a set there are no edges between it members. Is allowed to has vertices without edges. Notation: $G[X,Y]$.

title: Isolated graph
definition: No edges.

title: Complete bipartite graph
definition: All vertices of a X partition shares edge with all vertices of the partition Y and vice-versa.On $n$ vertices $G[X,Y]$, with $|X| = r$ and $|Y| = s$ number of elements, the  number of edges are: $r.s \leq \frac{n^2}{4}$.

title: The star graph
definition: It is a bipartite graph where one of the sets has just one member.

title: Grid graph
definition: Also known as square graph, it is a $x \times y$ graph, where the vertices set is the Cartesian product of $x \times y$. And the adjacency between two vertices is determinated by the equality of its abscissas or ordereds, and plus the difference of $\pm1$ between its abscissas or ordereds.

title: Isomorphic Graphs
definition: Two graphs $G_1$ and $G_2$ that there is a 1-1 onto a bijection function from $V_{(G_1)}$ to $V_{(G_2)}$ preserving adjacency.

title: N-cube (Hypercube) graph
definition: $Q_n := \{$ $0-1$ vector (nodes), such that any two nodes have an edge between them exactly when they differ in $1$ coordinate$\}$.

title: Planar Graph
definition: Is a graph that can be drawn in the plane such that edges can meet only their corresponding vertices.

title: Subgraph
definition: A subgraph $F$ of a graph $G$ is a graph that uses a subset of the vertices of $G$, such that: $V_{(F)} \leq V_{(G)}$ and $E_{(F)} \leq E_{(G)}$.

title: Complement of a graph
definition: The complement $C$ of $G$ is whose vertex set $V_{(C)}=V_{(G)}$ and the edges are the pairs of the non-adjacentb vertices of $G$.

title: Incidence Matrix
definition: Is the $n \times m$. $M_G := (m_{ve})$. $m_ve$ is the number of times $(0,1,2,...)$ that a vertex $v$ and edge $e$ are incident.

title: Adjacency Matrix
definition: Is the $n \times n$ . $A_G := (a_{uv})$. a_{uv} is the number of edges joining the vertices $u$ and $v$. In case of loops, it counts two edges.

title: Isolated vertex
definition: A vertex with degree equals to $0$.

title: Eigenvalue
definition: An Eigenvalue of a matrix $M$ is a complex number given by $M_x = \lambda_x$, where $x$ is a vector, called an eigenvector of $M$ and $\lambda \in \mathbb{C}$ (is a complex number).

title: Walk
definition: A walk in a graph $G$ is a sequence of nodes (vertices) $w = v_0e_1,v_1e_2,v_2e_3,\cdots,v_{l-1}e_l,v_le_{l+1}$ where the terms are alternating vertices and edges of $G$ (not necessarily distinct) such that $v_{i-1}$, and $v_i$ are the end points of $e_i, 1 \leq i \leq l$.

title: Path
definition: A path is a walk which does not repeat any vertices.

title: Cycle
definition: A cycle in $G$ is a closed path, and it requires at least $3$ vertices.

title: Hamiltonian path
definition: Is a path that traverses all the vertices of $V$.

title: Hamiltonian cycle
definition: Is a cycle that traverses all vertices of $V$ exactly once.

title: Hamiltonian graph
definition: Is a graph $G$ that has a Hamiltonian cycle.

title: Face
definition: Is defined by a minimal cycle in a plannar graph $G$.

title: Chord
definition: A chord of a cycle is an edge or path of $G$ formed by two (or more) non-adjacent vertices relative to the cycle.

title: k-connected
definition: Is a graph you need remove $\geq k$ edge(s) to disconnect it.

title: Spanning subgraph
definition: Is a subgraph of $G$ obtained by removing some or all edges.

title: Induced subgraph
definition: Is a subgraph of $G$ obtained by vertex deletion, therefore in this graph also the edges related with the deleted vertex are erased.

title: Genus
definition: Is the smallest $g$ such that we can draw the graph on a suface $g$, without intersecting edges.

title: Dual Graph
definition: Is when we add a vertex in the interior of each graph's face of $G$, and one in the outer face of the plan, and connecting with edges the vertices of the faces that share edges in $G$, then forming a subgraph $G'$.

title: Distance
definition: The distance between any $2$ vertices $u,v \in V$ is the length of a shortest path connecting $u$ and $v$.

title: Diameter
definition: The diameter of a graph $G$ is the largest distance between any two vertices of $G$.

title: Infinite Diameter
definition: It happens when the graph is disconnected.

title: Girth
definition: Is the length of the shortest cycle in a graph $G$.

title: Euler Trail
definition: Is a walk that passes exactly once through each edge of a graph $G$.

title: Euler Tour
definition: Is a walk that passes exactly once through each edge of a graph $G$, but it is also a closed path.

title: Even graph
definition: Is a graph whoose degrees of all vertices are even.

title: Proper coloring
definition: Also known as vertex proper coloring, is when the vertices of a graph receive a color property given by a set of $k$ colors, such that any two adjacent vertices share a same common color of this set.

title: $k$-coloring
definition: Is a proper vertex coloring that only uses $k$ colors.

title: Tree
definition: Is an acyclic (with no cycles) and connected graph.

title: Leaf
definition: A leaf of a tree is a vertex of degree equals to $1$.

title: Subtree
definition: It is a subgraph of $G$, which is a tree.

title: Spanning tree
definition: Is a subtree of $G$, which is also a spanning subgraph.

title: Automorphism
definition: Is an isomorphism from $G$ to itself.

title: Independent set
definition: It is a set of vertices that are not adjacent with any members of this set.

title: Maximum independent set
definition: It is a set of vertices that are not adjacent with any members of this set. Also this set is the set that has the maximum cardinality in terms of size.

title: Stability number / Independence number $\alpha(G)$
definition: Is the size of a maximum independent set of a graph.

title: Clique
definition: Is a subgraph of a graph $G$, isomorphic to some $K_m$ (any $m$).

title: Clique number $\alpha(\overline{G}) = \omega(G) $
definition: Is the size (maximum cardinality) of the largest clique in $G$.

title: Claw-free Graph
definition: It is when a graph $G$ do not contains a complete bipartite induced subgraph $K_{1,3}$.

title: Chromatic number $\chi(G)$
definition: Is the smallest number of colors we need to color the vertices of $G$, such that no two vertices which are neighbors have the same color.

title: Matching
definition: Is a collection of edges of $G$, which do not overlap (not share a vertex).

title: Complete matching
definition: In $G$ (bipartite graph with $|V_2| \geq |V_1|$) is a matching shuch that each vertex in $V_1$ gets covered (by some edge of the matching).

title: Directed Graph (digraph)
definition: Every edge $e$, in a directed graph $D$ has exactly one tail and one head.

title: Incidence Matrix
definition: Is the of digraph is $n \times m$ matrix $M_D := [M_{v,e}]$. Where $+1$ if $v$ is the tail of $e$. $-1$ if $v$ is the head of $e$. $0$ else.

title: Indegree
definition: Of a vertex in a digraph is the number of edges $e$ in $(\overline G)$ whose head is $v$.

title: Outdegree
definition: Of a vertex in a digraph is the number of the edges $e$ in $(\overline G)$ whose tail is $v$.

title: Line Graph
definition: Of a given graph $G$ (denotated by $L(G)$) is the graph that associates/assign to each edge of $G$ a vertex (of $L(G)$) in such a way that two verices in $L(G)$ are joined by an edge $<=>$ their corresponding edges in $G$ share a vertex in $G$.

title: Internally-disjoint paths
definition: Given $x$ and $y$ two vertices of $G$, where $x \neq y$, $xy$-paths $P_1$ and  $P_2$ are internally disjoint if they don't have any internal vertices in common and $V(P_1) \cap V(P_2) = \{x,y\}$.

title: Local connectivity $p(x,y)$
definition: Given $x$ and $y$ two non-adjacent vertices of $V(G)$, and  $x \neq y$. The local connectivity is the maximum number of internally disjoint paths between $x$ and $y$ of smaller size.

title: Vertex cut
definition: A $xy$-vertex cut is a subset $S$ of $V(G) \setminus \{x,y\}$ where $G-S$ disconect $x$ from $y$.

title: Local cut $c(x,y)$
definition: Is the maximum number of vertices required in any $xy$-vertex cut to disconnect $x$ to $y$.

title: Cycle exchange
definition: $G$ is a conected graph, and $C$ a cycle created from a subset of $V(G)$. To create a new circle $C'$ from $C$ without change its length, given two non-consecutive vertices $x$ and $y$ in $C$ such that $xy$ and $x^+y^+$ edges are in $G$, we bring those edges to $C$ and then delete edges $xx^+$ and $yy^+$, this edges override creates $C'$ and characterists the cycle exchange.

title: Bridge
definition: It is a set of edges of $G$ that has it start and end in a cycle $C$.

title: Attached vertices
definition: Are vertices from a cycle that also contains edges that are not part of the edges of the cycle.

title: Maximal
definition: with respect to some quantity.

title: Maximum
definition: with respect to inclusion.

title: The handshaking lemma
definition: In any graph $\sum d(v) = 2|E|$

title: Menger’s Theorem (Undirected Vertex Version)
definition: In any graph $G(x,y)$ where $x$ and $y$ are nonadjacent, the maximum number of pairwise internally disjoint $xy$-paths is equal to the minimum number of vertices in an $xy$-vertex-cut, that is, $p(x,y)=c(x,y)$

title: Theorem 9.2
definition: If $G$ has at least one pair of nonadjacent vertices, $(G)=min\{p(x,y):x,y \in V(G), x \neq y, xy \notin E(G)\}$

title: Theorem of exercise 1.3.8 (Kneser graph)
definition: $KG2$, $n$ is isomorphic to the complement of $L(Kn), n \geq 5$.
